reviewText:
Early Access Review

GameplayRoguelikes are characterized by a list of gameplay mechanics, such as procedural level generation, permadeath, turn-based gameplay, and randomized loot. The latter includes random stat generation for equipment and unidentified potions and scrolls. This game includes all of them, but unfortunately not much else. As it stands right now, the game is a barebones roguelike in terms of gameplay. Compared to its competition in terms of gameplay, the game is running far behind. If Claustrophobia wants to stand out - even while in early access - it should have gameplay elements unique to it. Be it a fusion of gameplay elements from different genres, or simply a new set of mechanics not seen before.

The gameplay is fairly simple. You start your character by picking a class, and (if desired) you can do some very minor modifications. You are subsequently dropped in a dungeon where you get to fight a very small variety of standard mobs. Think of the rats, zombies, skeletons, and spiders kind. Your character has a set of abilities that cost 'mana/stamina' to use, but at the very start you will not have access to many of them. You defeat the aforementioned enemies, pick up whatever gear you find and wear it if its an upgrade or sell it if it's a downgrade if you encounter a shop.

ControlsThe game controls pretty well. The animations and UI are very indicative of the commands you give, and that's pretty much all that can be said about it. WIth turn-based gameplay in the standard roguelike fashion there is not much to controls. While the game has fairly little 'meat' to it as of yet, the controls are not convoluted. What I like is that you can bring out the map and click on locations to auto-walk there. Skill use and target selection is also very intuitive with a nice layout indicating range.

DifficultySo far the difficulty of the game is lacking. While there are traps around, I have yet to step on one by accident. My juggernaut without any trapfinding skill is pretty much capable of seeing and disarming every trap so far encountered. While disarming a trap can still fail (and deal damage in the process), the game's health regeneration mechanics make this trivial.

Every turn you automatically recover health as long as you are not starving (in which case there is simply no health recovery). While enemies don't seem to roam through the dungeons (they stay nicely put in their enclosed rooms) waiting and healing is not dangerous at all. With the common availability of food, it is even possible to easily kill bosses simply by beelining to the entrance stairs and safely recovering your health on the previous dungeon floor, before you can resume killing the boss again.

As is common with roguelikes, positioning is key. You don't want enemies to surround you. Instead, enemies should be funneled through so only one enemy at a time can engage you. With the dungeon level design this is fairly easy to do. There is (so far, as I have discovered) only one enemy type with a ranged attack who can foul this tactic.

Gold seems to be too common in the game, especially since you can sell the gear you don't use. So far I have been able to purchase any gear I wanted from the shops, which means your character is more often than not well supplied with equipment of fairly high strength.

LevelingWith the aforementioned ease of getting equipment, I often even forget to level because the 2 points I can add to my stats makes barely an impact based on the gear upgrades I'm getting. This makes the attribute system rather pointless. Even worse, item requirements are not tied to the base score of an attribute, but to the total score. Thus, you could wear +strength items to sufficiently increase you strength in order to wear the gear you want. This often makes me forget 2 attribute scores are given every time you level.

Every odd level you also get 2 further points to level in a skill tree and a specific ability. This system is really too convoluted. First you will need to find a skillbook of the ability you would like to use. Then you have to read it, but reading it requires a minimum amount of points in a certain skill (e.g., defense skill, or assassination skill). If you have enough points in that, you can read the book but haven't learned the skill yet. You then have to spent one point into the ability in order to learn and use it.

This system should be reworked, because it makes you require 3 things before you can use an ability, while abilities should be fairly important as they diversify combat.

GraphicsGraphically, the game reminds me a lot of Pixel Dungeon (free mobile game for android devices), which actually does a much better job gameplay wise. It is nice that this game changes the looks of your character based on the gear being worn. The graphical style is good, and makes also for a clear UI. Unfortunately so far there is fairly little variation in the graphics, but this is not a point I will stress too much since it is still in early access, and graphics aren't the most important factor in roguelikes.

Final JudgementThe Good
Nice graphical style
Very clear UI
The Bad
Bland and lacking content - nothing this game has to offer is unique to this title as it carries to bare minimum of what would constitute a roguelike
It is far too easy based on its core mechanics (health recovery per turn, ease of getting gold, dungeon layouts making enemy-funneling easy)
The leveling system is not that great. Convolution in one part, and barely significant in the other.
No variety in gameplay. The skills are limited due to the leveling system, and the currently available skills don't seem to have that much of an impact. In games like Tales of Maj'Eyal skills are essential for survival - here they barely seem to make a dent.
The game does what all other roguelikes do, but nothing extra. It currently lacks a lot of content and doesn't stand out among its peers. This is basically the harshest criticism of the game there is, because making a roguelike (or roguelite) nowadays seems common practice among indie developers. For now it is just another roguelike"

Early Access Review

I like this game.  Claustrophobia has options; lots and lots of options!  Different classes, armor and weapons, shops, and spells for every class, not just the mages.  Now add unknown scrolls and potions, traps, teleporters, and dealing with hunger,  Then add the management of character stat points for each level as well as dealing with your choice of specialties and you quickly realize Claustrophobia is a different game every time you play.

Another thing I enjoy about this game is it's fair.  The best way I can explain it is every time I have died, it is because I made a mistake and I know it.  Thismay not be a good thing if you're a roguelike veteran who makes very few mistakes.  Personally, I prefer strategy over luck-based gameplay and Claustrophobia does a good job of making the game tough, but fair.

I'm going to confess that I'm not a fan of roguelikes but I am having a blast with this game.  It feels like a good dungeon delving RPG with tough objectives.  I die a lot, but I get a little better every time I play.  I look forward to seeing how Claustrophobia develops further; it's quite playable already.

My first impressions YouTube video:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DgAmTVaahfg

Nothing needs to be said more then this:  Don't judge this game by the simple graphics you see.

This game is mega fun, especially if you are an RPG dungeon searching fan.  Period.

It is turned based, meaning for every action you take or over movement you make, the monsters also take a turn.  You can't out-move or click your mouse fast to get extra strikes on them... that will get you killed fast, trust me, hehe.  Instead, take your time, plan strategically in your battles and movement, and that is where this game shines.'

There is tons of loot, store 'rooms' inside the dungeon that you can find where you can pawn your junk and buy needed gear.  There is level ups that give you points to add to stats, new special abilities/spells to add, and new perks to unlock.  Add to this all the real feeling you get of 'exploring' the dungeon as rooms are revealed from the darkness as you explore them, and this game is a simple, but deep and very fun little gem.

This game is worth three times it's asking price.  After playing it, I am hooked, and if I had to go back and buy it again, I'd gladly give $14.99 USD for it after spending some time with it!  It's THAT good.  Must Buy" if you like RPGs and especially if you believe a games heart isn't in its graphics.

Update-- Back when I wrote this review, that was how I felt about the game. It seems the developer shares the same sentiment as the game is now officially abandonware. Yup, this game will be early access and unfinished forever.

It really is a thrill and many of us would agree that you feel crushed when you die in a Rogue-like game, but from the ashes you rise again!

Rouge-likes are supposed to be hard!

This obsoletes most of the other things in the game. Build health, build just enough damage to kill things respectabley and not an iota more. Build defensive stats and evasion. Horde food.

Early Access Review

First off, I'm not saying that this is a bad game. As it is, Claustrophobia is a fully fuctional roguelike dungeon crawler that certainly captures overly unforgiving nature of the genre. However, this is not to say that the game is all that great either, especially when compared to other (very) similar games.

While most roguelikes tend to follow a similar gameplay regime, Claustrophobia does very little to make itself stand out from other games, namely Dungeons of Dredmor. Aesthetically, it uses the same 3D top-down dungeon view as Dredmor, and the cartoony style of the sprites is very similar as well. Even the title screen appears to have taken influence with the logos using almost matching fonts and the backdrop depicting a very similar scene. And while Dungeons of Dredmor implemented an extensive skill system and an imaginative cast of baddies, Claustrophobia seriously lacks in the character customization department. And the enemies? Zombies, rats, spiders; Bland, bland, bland.
They even reused the same tileset across different floors. The game just seems to lack any creativity whatsoever.

Again, I'm not saying that this is a terrible game, but I don't understand why anyone would choose to play it when there are far better games elsewhere. Maybe it's still to early to judge since it's still in early access, but seriously, if you're going to spend $5 then you may as well just buy Dungeons of Dredmor (it's the same price by the way).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Abandoned Game
I bought this game due to the fact that, it looked pretty good, graphic-wise, and the fact that I like rogue-like games.
Well, I'm disappointed, the developer, who seemd to want to create something fun, has pretty much abandoned the development of this game. Until the developer decides to do something, this review remains negative. I can't recommend this Early Access title, and I won't. Has potential, but no kinetic energy, as of yet.

The game IS fun, it's very fun! But with the lack of features, the lack of support, and the fact that the dev. no longer responds is a big issue. When the developer comes back, I'll fix this review.

Gameplay:
It's the same as any other rogue-like game; take turns, open doors, kill monsters, collect loot, and travel farther down. I hope for an option to keep your character's stats, rather than just looks (and maybe even name?), as it can get extremely repetitive just re-statting characters. There are multiple items throughout the game, and many pathways you can take. Luck based game, you either open a door a lucky-man, or open a door and die as an un-lucky man.

Story:
The story is what you make of it, it's a role-playing game (duh). The only thing you know is that you have to survive and dwell deeper into the tower(?).

Graphics:
The graphics are simple, which is expected, and it can only appeal to fans of the genre. Plus, as a bonus, you can change textures/art in the folder, which is always nice. The art is not clunky, not too serious, but just right.

Classes:
This is one of the better elements of this game, albeit the short amount of classes (3). You have your basic classes: rogue, warrior, shaman, and archer (archer is the best in my opinion). Instead of being forced into the game with the generic class skills, you have skills/skill trees you can choose before you get into game; warrior's can use the shaman's black magic, same applies with rogue and so-forth. It's fun to mix up classes and skills, just to see how far I can get with said skill-set(s).

6/10
This game easily could have been an 8/10, but due to having no-updates (being in Early Access), I can't recommend this. Unless, of course, you're looking for an unpolished rogue-like game. The game itself is fantastic, so far, but it REALLY needs some updates. The lack of armor/weaponry, buffs, enemies, textures (same textures), and other things, are totally fine, but the fact is, the developer hasn't been here to take care of that stuff, which is disappointing.

Personally I think this is a really interesting game. Yes, the whole dungeon crawl premise is being over done, but I feel like this game captures it pretty well without making it overly difficult. A bit complex, yes, but it balances everything out with the equipment you can get and if you have the mind for it you will overcome any challenge thrown at you.

The game randomly generates the floors of a dungeon, with certain things being certain per floor, such as shops so you can spend the hard earned gold from killing monsters. Each class starts with two skills, and earns more from shops, searching bookshelves, and possible monster drops. The hunger system is actually a really interesting mechanic that adds that extra layer and helps to seperate it from other games of the genre. If your character gets to the point you are starving (I say if because food is quite generous in the game, unless you get really unlucky) your health regen stops entirely, making your only way to gain health potions and leveling up (which will become a lot more difficult even with great gear). You generally find the food on the floor or in boxes, and you can find rotten food for those times when you are real desperate and NEED your health regen back to get back into the fight.
